Phylogeny, comparative morphology, mating behaviour, evolution and ecology of scorpions: A multidisciplinary approach
Project
Phylogeny, comparative morphology, mating Behaviour, evolution and ecology of scorpions: A multidisciplinary approach
View
Putative parallel Evolution in The Northern Scorpion - Paruroctonus boreus
Project
Under the supervision of Dr. Zachariah Gompert and in collaboration with Drs. Lorenzo Prendini (AMNH) and Robert W. Bryson (University of Washington), I am interested in investigating intra and interspecific morphological and genetic variation in the Northern Scorpion Paruroctonus boreus, including how selection has acted upon this variation and if and what maintains divergent or distinct forms in specific populations. We will be targeting populations that are found in distinct habitat or regions, such as high elevation populations and facultative dune populations. Our preliminary studies have already distinguished some interesting patterns in interspecific morphological variation. Literature addressing the variation in color of this species often attributes this variation to edaphic factors (Sissom and Franke 1981, Haradon 1985). If disparate populations exhibit homogeneous morphological traits with shared candidate loci, parallel evolution has occurred, thus informing us on the nature of natural selection and the repeatability of evolution. We will be using a restriction-fragment based molecular approach, creating an artificial reference genome, and using resequence data to identify variable nucleotides that may represent candidate loci for specific phenotypes and traits.
